<s>20<\s> 30 
to the Postglacial deposits: <s>, but<\s> One solitary instance however of 
its occurrence viewed side by side with the abundance of remains 
of animals dwelling in a temperate zone and even of southern 
origin as <u>R. megarhinus<\u> does not alter the views I have advanced 
as to the comparatively temperate conditions <s>of the climate<\s> under 
which they lived as compared with the severity of the 
Postglacial climate. It would indeed be rash to believe that the 
whole of the animals found in the <s>c<\s>Crayford pit were fitted 
to endure the severity of limate in which the Musk sheep 
now lives. I should therefore be inclined to consider it 
the skull of an animal that had strayed from its usual 
arctic haunts in the winter into the country more usually 
occupied by the animals found along with it. Nor indeed is 
there anything impossible in this hypothesis In North 
America for example, the Bison ranged, in Hearnes time over 
the open rushy plains as far to the north and east as the 
Southern shore of Athabasca Lake on Lat 59[degree] while on the 
colder shores of Hudsons Bay a little to the north of Fort 
Churchill on the same latitude that explorer found 
proofs of the presence of Musk Sheep. In an unusually 
severe winter there would be nothing extraordinary in 
the latter animal occasionally straying south of Athabasca 
lake and its bones being mingled with those of the Elk 
<u>Waipiti and Bison<\u>. That the animal was very rare in the 
Postglacial deposits in Europe is proved by its having been found 
only in nine places. In Siberia although only three instances are 
on record of its having been found, it is probably abundant in 
the vast unexplored stores of remains in the frozen gravel of 
the Tundras and especially at Seratoi Ness. Its rarity would 
imply that its headquarters were in some district to the North 
and East of France and Germany in Postglacial times and 
that it only inhabited the districts in which it is found during 
an unusually severe season which would drive it from 
its usual haunts. We have thus traced the Ovibos Moschatus
